						THURSDAY 19 APRIL 22:30 BST - BBC TWO


						FROM PROGRAMME PRODUCER CAROL RUBRA
					
					Hello, 



VIRGINIA SHOOTINGS


For the relatives and friends who have been struggling to understand why a student was able to shoot 32 students and teachers at Virginia Tech University, the news that the gunman had prepared a video and sent it to a US television network must have been a horrific twist in events. 


Questions continue over whether Cho Seung Hui should have been given more psychiatric help early on and whether the killings could have been prevented. Added to that now are questions over whether the video should have been broadcast at all: the police handling the investigation say it shouldn't have been. We'll be discussing the issues.



ALBERTO GONZALES


US Attorney General Alberto Gonzales is being questioned today by the Senate Judiciary Committee over his controversial decision to sack eight US attorneys who, allegedly, showed insufficient "loyalty" to the Bush administration. The question for his boss, George Bush, is whether he can keep his loyal Attorney General amid the growing pressure to fire him. Laura Trevelyan will have the latest from the hearing. 


CALLED TO ACCOUNT


Should Tony Blair be called to account over the war in Iraq? The Guardian correspondent, Richard Norton Taylor, asked two top lawyers, Philippe Sands QC for the prosecution and Julian Knowles for the defence, to interview 12 witnesses, including former cabinet ministers and civil servants, to assess whether the prime minister should be indicted for the war crime of aggression. He turned their findings into a play, which opens tonight. The two lawyers will debate the case for and against on the programme.


ROAD SAFETY


Every day, one and a quarter million people are killed on the world's roads, and 50 million are injured.   Most of the victims are in the world's poorer countries. 


Ahead of the first ever UN global road safety week, we follow a road safety campaigner from India - himself paralysed in a road accident - as he travels to India and Brazil to find out if anything can be done to halt the rise in deaths on the roads.


Join us at 10.30pm.


Carol
